abstract.p: Brief interview with Mike Magnuson, author of novel The Fire Gospels; photo (S)

block.p: Mike Magnuson is the author of ''The Fire Gospels,'' a novel.

Q: In your book, an evangelistic weatherman named Lucky Littlefield almost becomes a god to people in a rural Wisconsin town that is suffering a terrible drought. In a scientific age, can weather and natural disasters still have a religious hold on people?
Mike Magnuson is the author of ''The Fire Gospels,'' a novel.

Q: In your book, an evangelistic weatherman named Lucky Littlefield almost becomes a god to people in a rural Wisconsin town that is suffering a terrible drought. In a scientific age, can weather and natural disasters still have a religious hold on people?

A: They sure can. During the fires in Florida, people did get together to pray for rain and for the firefighters. This terrible weather we've been having, people are inclined to think of it as biblical. For the last few years, it's gotten worse and worse every year. And what else can we do except feel helpless in the face of it?

There's a scientific explanation, of course -- global warming -- but at the millennium there's all this prophecy that God's going to crush us for being bad. Pat Robertson even called for hurricanes to strike Florida this year because Disney World had a gay weekend and he couldn't stand it.
Q: Is the weather punishing us?

A: Of course not. Coincidence is not a divine act. Bad stuff happens. Pompeii happened. But we're so afraid our lives are just going to end -- like a deer's -- that we construe the environment to mean something it doesn't really mean.
Q: What's your source of comfort?
A: I hold with Descartes and Sartre that it's a joy to be alive. It doesn't have to be more than that.
